<issue_start><issue_comment>Title: Some What's new posts aren't rendering correctly on Docs Site
username_0: It looks like some what's new posts are missing body content.
<issue_comment>username_0: @username_1 is troubleshooting it was brought our attention by Bill and Nic and Mark B so it's higher priority .
<issue_comment>username_1: The pages that fail to display in the help overlay aren't regular docs pages, they're "What's new" announcements. These pages are special in that they live in a different part of the repository and have their own endpoint for getting the JSON content.

The service that powers the in-product help is unaware that these are special pages, and it's attempting to get the content for (what it thinks is) a page (when it's really a post). Here's the query that the in-product help experience is using:

```graphql
query ($id: ID!) {
  docs {
    library {
      article(id: $id) {
        url
        id
        title
        body
      }
    }
  }
}
```

And when you provide it an ID for a what's new posts, will return `body: null`. Here's an ID to test that out:

```json
{
  "id": "RE9DU3wvd2hhdHMtbmV3LzIwMjEvMDYvZGF0YS1pbmdlc3QtZHJpbGwtZG93bi98NjBlNWI2NjMxOTZhNjc5NWM4NGVhMDgy"
}
```

In order to remedy this, we have possible solutions:
üÖ∞Ô∏è We update the service so that, if it determines that an "article" is a what's new post, it uses a _different_ JSON endpoint to get the content.
üÖ±Ô∏è We update the service so that it doesn't show what's new posts when searching for help to show the user (the links will still be present in the left sidebar).

@username_0 Your call on which path you want to go down and when you think we should do this work.
<issue_comment>username_0: Let's go with üÖ∞Ô∏è<issue_closed>

column6:
<issue_start><issue_comment>Title: Remove "military-grade cryptography" phrase
username_0: Military Grade cryptography as a term is problematic as it lacks clear definition today.

Most modern cryptography is 'military grade' and use of cryptography by civilian and military alike is similar and commonplace.
What was once a hip marketing buzzword now looks dated and does not speak to the sheer magnitude of the computational power that secures Bitcoin.

I think bitcoin dot org removing this statement with a more abstract "mathematics and energy", with a quick note on why these two concepts protect Bitcoin would be a good move to deprecate this dated marketing phrase and give the reader a better understanding of the fundamental concepts protecting their money.
<issue_comment>username_1: Thanks for contributing!

1.  I agree that "military-grade cryptography" is a bit vague and could be replaced as suggested or even replaced simply with "cryptography" or "strong cryptography"
2. "Proof of Work" should not be capitalized
3. I'm less enthusiastic about the other changes as this is an overview page and also it might not be obvious that the "signatures" refer to the "mathematics" in the first sentence.
<issue_comment>username_2: LGTM, "military-grade cryptography" is a bad term and the changes you made read much more clear.

If one other contributor agrees on merging this, it will get merged.
<issue_comment>username_3: Can you hyperlink "proof of work" to a definition - so the user can be prompted to read about it further?
Also the first time "proof of work" is mentioned it should be followed by (POW) or (PoW) - this distinguishes it as jargon for a methodology. 

Example:
```
proof of work ([PoW](https://en.bitcoin.it/wiki/Proof_of_work))	

proof-of-work ([PoW](https://en.bitcoin.it/wiki/Proof_of_work))

```

proof of work ([PoW](https://en.bitcoin.it/wiki/Proof_of_work))	

proof-of-work ([PoW](https://en.bitcoin.it/wiki/Proof_of_work))


A link to https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cryptography_standards
may also be useful some where...

---

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Proof_of_work
https://en.bitcoin.it/wiki/Proof_of_work
https://nakamotoinstitute.org/rpow/
https://nakamotoinstitute.org/finney/rpow/index.html

![Screen Shot 2021-01-19 at 10 40 28 PM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/152159/105124112-6b3b0380-5aa7-11eb-9a79-d606d30bd339.png)

![Screen Shot 2021-01-19 at 10 40 02 PM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/152159/105124115-6b3b0380-5aa7-11eb-8a98-f36ee0ca8e19.png)

![Screen Shot 2021-01-19 at 10 34 14 PM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/152159/105123694-86f1da00-5aa6-11eb-9bb5-422c044ec2f1.png)


###  These are only suggestions on how the content may be improved.
### Otherwise the changes are satisfactory as is.
<issue_comment>username_0: Thank you for the suggestion Randy, I have updated with hyperlinks to PoW and ECDSA on the bitcoin wiki.
The bitcoin wiki:ECDSA article might not be complete enough, do yourself or others have another preferred link? (wp:ECDSA over bitcoin wiki:ECDSA?)
<issue_comment>username_2: Nice work on this. Merging it now.

column5:
[{'action': 'opened', 'author': 'nairb774', 'comment_id': None, 'datetime': '2020-08-11 00:29:27+00:00', 'masked_author': 'username_0', 'text': 'Context: https://preliminary.istio.io/latest/blog/2020/proxy-cert/

With the work in https://github.com/istio/istio/issues/23583 and https://github.com/istio/istio/pull/25363, long term this blog post is likely to age poorly. On the other hand, I think there is a more elegant solution that became possible with the 1.6 release, and likely is going to be more maintainable for users over the long run. The one major downside, currently, is that it makes use of an undocumented setting.

First, the way in which this could be better implemented. Rather than including a manually configured proxy sidecar to mint certificates, we can make use of the `proxy.istio.io/config` and `sidecar.istio.io/userVolumeMount` annotations to tweak how the normally injected sidecar behaves. This assumes that the `istio-sidecar-injector` config map is mostly unmodified, but I've been able to successfully use the following pod annotations to provide certificates to our Datadog agent (in a similar way to how the prometheus stuff is done):

```yaml
annotations:
  proxy.istio.io/config: |
    proxyMetadata:
      OUTPUT_CERTS: /etc/istio-certs
  sidecar.istio.io/userVolumeMount: |
    {"istio-certs": {"mountPath": "/etc/istio-certs"}}
  traffic.sidecar.istio.io/excludeOutboundIPRanges: "0.0.0.0/0"
```

Note: This does require an `emptyDir` volume to be provided, but that should be fairly self explanatory.

As I mentioned before, this takes advantage of the undocumented `proxyMetadata` field in the [ProxyConfig](https://istio.io/docs/reference/config/istio.mesh.v1alpha1/#ProxyConfig) to set the `OUTPUT_CERTS` environment variable like the existing blog post does. If the `proxyMetadata` field were documented, then the annotations like above would be a much more sustainable approach to provisioning certificates than the previous manual container configuration. The other option would be to have some sort of `outputCerts` option which, depending on how much magic is desired, could be a path to export the certs to, a volume name to mount and export the certs to, or just a boolean indicating that a volume should be provisioned with a predetermined name and the certs written there.

No matter the direction, some sort of improved documentation in this space could go a long way for enabling this uncommon, but powerful escape hatch to be easier to maintain.', 'title': 'Possible alternative solution to "Provision a certificate and key for an application without sidecars"', 'type': 'issue'}]
column6:
<issue_start><issue_comment>Title: Possible alternative solution to "Provision a certificate and key for an application without sidecars"
username_0: Context: https://preliminary.istio.io/latest/blog/2020/proxy-cert/

With the work in https://github.com/istio/istio/issues/23583 and https://github.com/istio/istio/pull/25363, long term this blog post is likely to age poorly. On the other hand, I think there is a more elegant solution that became possible with the 1.6 release, and likely is going to be more maintainable for users over the long run. The one major downside, currently, is that it makes use of an undocumented setting.

First, the way in which this could be better implemented. Rather than including a manually configured proxy sidecar to mint certificates, we can make use of the `proxy.istio.io/config` and `sidecar.istio.io/userVolumeMount` annotations to tweak how the normally injected sidecar behaves. This assumes that the `istio-sidecar-injector` config map is mostly unmodified, but I've been able to successfully use the following pod annotations to provide certificates to our Datadog agent (in a similar way to how the prometheus stuff is done):

```yaml
annotations:
  proxy.istio.io/config: |
    proxyMetadata:
      OUTPUT_CERTS: /etc/istio-certs
  sidecar.istio.io/userVolumeMount: |
    {"istio-certs": {"mountPath": "/etc/istio-certs"}}
  traffic.sidecar.istio.io/excludeOutboundIPRanges: "0.0.0.0/0"
```

Note: This does require an `emptyDir` volume to be provided, but that should be fairly self explanatory.

As I mentioned before, this takes advantage of the undocumented `proxyMetadata` field in the [ProxyConfig](https://istio.io/docs/reference/config/istio.mesh.v1alpha1/#ProxyConfig) to set the `OUTPUT_CERTS` environment variable like the existing blog post does. If the `proxyMetadata` field were documented, then the annotations like above would be a much more sustainable approach to provisioning certificates than the previous manual container configuration. The other option would be to have some sort of `outputCerts` option which, depending on how much magic is desired, could be a path to export the certs to, a volume name to mount and export the certs to, or just a boolean indicating that a volume should be provisioned with a predetermined name and the certs written there.

No matter the direction, some sort of improved documentation in this space could go a long way for enabling this uncommon, but powerful escape hatch to be easier to maintain.

column5:
[{'action': 'opened', 'author': 'WebFreak001', 'comment_id': None, 'datetime': '2019-01-02T17:38:48Z', 'masked_author': 'username_0', 'text': 'Adds the [Discord](https://discordapp.com/) chat link for "D Language Code Club" (previously known as "D Code Club" and "Wilds Code Club") to the Community section. (in the following referred to as "Server") Discord is a lot like to Slack

The server currently has 378 members, where we usually have around 100 online users. (comparable to IRC) It is the official chat of [dplug](https://code.dlang.org/packages/dplug), [code-d](https://github.com/Pure-D/code-d) and [PowerNex](https://github.com/PowerNex/PowerNex). We have topic channels around general Programming, web development and OS development, a user-submitted D resources collection, a user-submitted D projects collection and a News channel about D news from the Announce forum and announcing new dub projects. There are also some off-topic channels.

We help a lot of users with their programming questions on the server.', 'title': 'Add Discord join link to the community section', 'type': 'issue'}

column6:
<issue_start><issue_comment>Title: Add Discord join link to the community section
username_0: Adds the [Discord](https://discordapp.com/) chat link for "D Language Code Club" (previously known as "D Code Club" and "Wilds Code Club") to the Community section. (in the following referred to as "Server") Discord is a lot like to Slack

The server currently has 378 members, where we usually have around 100 online users. (comparable to IRC) It is the official chat of [dplug](https://code.dlang.org/packages/dplug), [code-d](https://github.com/Pure-D/code-d) and [PowerNex](https://github.com/PowerNex/PowerNex). We have topic channels around general Programming, web development and OS development, a user-submitted D resources collection, a user-submitted D projects collection and a News channel about D news from the Announce forum and announcing new dub projects. There are also some off-topic channels.

We help a lot of users with their programming questions on the server.
<issue_comment>username_2: @thewilsonator please please don't merge changes to the front page without @CyberShadow's, @andralex's or my approval and in any case not after seven hours.
Also, (1) a change to the menu would need to be propagated to a lot of things (ddox, dub, forum, tour, visualD,...) and (2) there's the UX rule of not using more than eight items and we already overstretched that.
Then there's (3) the point that it's not official and we just promoted it to be official.

I don't object to this in general, but I think it deserves more than seven hours of review time.

column5:
[{'action': 'opened', 'author': 'hellais', 'comment_id': None, 'datetime': '2020-10-23 05:54:30+00:00', 'masked_author': 'username_0', 'text': 'A current challenge with responding to censorship events is the lack of immediate data in specific locations when reports of censorship emerge. To address this problem, we have been working on the creation of the OONI Probe Orchestration System, which aims to dynamically schedule and orchestrate OONI Probe tests (only applicable to probes that opt-in), particularly in response to emergent censorship events. For security reasons, the probe orchestration functionalities would be limited to OONI Probe tests already shipped as part of the apps and to URLs vetted as part of the Citizen Lab test lists.

As part of this proposed project, we aim to add probe orchestration support to the OONI Probe mobile app by implementing automatic testing via ‚Äúsilent push‚Äù. By giving users the possibility to opt-in to automatic testing, we would be able to instrument probes to dynamically gather measurements in response to emergent censorship events, without requiring the user to manually trigger the tests. Since all OONI measurements are openly published, this would support advocacy efforts and empower anti-censorship tool developers to rapidly release workarounds for impacted communities. 

Push notifications allow us to broadcast messages to all OONI Probe mobile app users around the world (or selectively, to OONI Probe mobile app users in specific countries). We will therefore make greater use of our push notification system to deliver relevant messages to end users to encourage testing, particularly in response to emergent censorship events. This will support rapid response and help increase testing coverage.

We will add backend support that will enable us to send push notifications which ask OONI Probe users to test a set of websites or to run specific experiments. This will be particularly useful during emergent censorship events, when a list of sites needs to get tested urgently. 

We will add frontend support so that members of the OONI team can configure the push notifications. If the frequency of push notifications starts to go up, we will expose richer configuration options in the settings to enable or disable certain notifications. We will also look at app metrics to understand how well these UX solutions work. We will continue to be cognizant of the risk of over-using push notifications during extended censorship events and we will maintain channels of communication with local community members to ensure that the frequency of push notifications are reasonable, necessary, and useful. 

Finally, we will add mobile app support so that OONI Probe mobile app users can receive push notifications and run experiments. This will involve designing a UI to tell users that we would like them to test a set of URLs now in their country and that this has come from a push notification. They will be shown the full list of sites they are going to test and either dismiss the message or run the desired experiment. We will ensure that this is consistent with our informed consent procedure and that this feature is safe and ethical. By doing this it will be possible during incident response to engage more users to test relevant sites.', 'title': '2.2 Improve Probe Orchestration system to dynamically schedule and orchestrate OONI Probe tests', 'type': 'issue'}

We can have have probes check in every X time and the backend tells them to $do-nothing or test something.

We should discuss if we want to implement silent push at all.', 'title': None, 'type': 'comment'}

I will take a look at enriching the parent epic with relevant issues and then closing it up.', 'title': None, 'type': 'comment'}]
column6:
<issue_start><issue_comment>Title: 2.2 Improve Probe Orchestration system to dynamically schedule and orchestrate OONI Probe tests
username_0: A current challenge with responding to censorship events is the lack of immediate data in specific locations when reports of censorship emerge. To address this problem, we have been working on the creation of the OONI Probe Orchestration System, which aims to dynamically schedule and orchestrate OONI Probe tests (only applicable to probes that opt-in), particularly in response to emergent censorship events. For security reasons, the probe orchestration functionalities would be limited to OONI Probe tests already shipped as part of the apps and to URLs vetted as part of the Citizen Lab test lists.

As part of this proposed project, we aim to add probe orchestration support to the OONI Probe mobile app by implementing automatic testing via ‚Äúsilent push‚Äù. By giving users the possibility to opt-in to automatic testing, we would be able to instrument probes to dynamically gather measurements in response to emergent censorship events, without requiring the user to manually trigger the tests. Since all OONI measurements are openly published, this would support advocacy efforts and empower anti-censorship tool developers to rapidly release workarounds for impacted communities. 

Push notifications allow us to broadcast messages to all OONI Probe mobile app users around the world (or selectively, to OONI Probe mobile app users in specific countries). We will therefore make greater use of our push notification system to deliver relevant messages to end users to encourage testing, particularly in response to emergent censorship events. This will support rapid response and help increase testing coverage.

We will add backend support that will enable us to send push notifications which ask OONI Probe users to test a set of websites or to run specific experiments. This will be particularly useful during emergent censorship events, when a list of sites needs to get tested urgently. 

We will add frontend support so that members of the OONI team can configure the push notifications. If the frequency of push notifications starts to go up, we will expose richer configuration options in the settings to enable or disable certain notifications. We will also look at app metrics to understand how well these UX solutions work. We will continue to be cognizant of the risk of over-using push notifications during extended censorship events and we will maintain channels of communication with local community members to ensure that the frequency of push notifications are reasonable, necessary, and useful. 

Finally, we will add mobile app support so that OONI Probe mobile app users can receive push notifications and run experiments. This will involve designing a UI to tell users that we would like them to test a set of URLs now in their country and that this has come from a push notification. They will be shown the full list of sites they are going to test and either dismiss the message or run the desired experiment. We will ensure that this is consistent with our informed consent procedure and that this feature is safe and ethical. By doing this it will be possible during incident response to engage more users to test relevant sites.
<issue_comment>username_0: The intention is to tell probes they should do something NOW (where now can be a window of X time).

We can have have probes check in every X time and the backend tells them to $do-nothing or test something.

We should discuss if we want to implement silent push at all.
<issue_comment>username_0: This is mostly done. I will take a look at enriching the parent epic with relevant issues and then closing it up.
